newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft/Apple deal not antitrust problem-lawyers.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft/Apple deal not antitrust problem-lawyers.

text.p: Microsoft's decision Wednesday to invest $150 million in Apple Computer is unlikely to raise antitrust issues and might even help competition, according to antitrust lawyers contacted by Reuters.

Apple Computer Inc adviser Steve Jobs announced that Microsoft Corp will buy the non-voting stock over the next three years, that the two companies will have broad cross-licensing agreements, and that Apple will bundle the Microsoft Internet Explorer browser with its Mac OS as the default browser.

"It could easily be this would improve competition within the industry as a whole," said Gordon Spivack, an antitrust lawyer with Coudert Brothers in New York. "Microsoft probably has an interest in helping Apple be one of the competing systems."
Steve Sunshine of Shearman and Sterling in Washington was equally untroubled.

"What's all the fuss?" he said. He said some people had raised questions about making Internet Explorer the default browser on the Mac OS. But he said that the Mac OS accounted for only a small percentage of overall personal computer sales.
"I don't see how (that) changes much of anything," he said of the decision to bundle the browser with the Mac OS. "The question of whether the platform has any vitality left is an open issue."
Analysts said the investment might deflect criticism that Microsoft has been unfairly dominating the computing industry. Federal antitrust regulators have been investigating Microsoft since 1989.
Helping Apple to remain competitive in the personal computer business could aid Microsoft's contention that it does not hold a monopoly in the computer software business, analysts said.
